concept.title: Run a script on remote nodes
concept.shortdesc: Specify the script you want to run and which nodes to run it on.

conbody.p: Use the bolt script run command to run existing scripts that you use or to combine the commands that you regularly run as part of sequence. When you run a script with , the script is transferred into a temporary directory on the remote system, run on that system, and then deleted.
You can run scripts in any language as long as the appropriate interpreter is installed on the remote system. This includes Bash, , or Python.

li.p: To run a script, specify the path to the script, and which nodes to run it on: bolt script run <PATH/TO/SCRIPT> --nodes <NODE NAME>,<NODE NAME>,<NODE NAME>bolt script run ../myscript.sh --nodes web5.mydomain.edu, web6.mydomain.edu
When executing on WinRM nodes, include the WinRM protocol in the nodes string: bolt script run <PATH/TO/SCRIPT> --nodes winrm://<NODE NAME> --user <USERNAME> --password <PASSWORD>

ul.li: To pass arguments to a script, specify them after the command. If an argument contain spaces or special characters, you must quote it: bolt script run myscript.sh 'echo hello'Argument values are passed literally and are not interpolated by the shell on the remote host. If you run bolt script run myscript.sh 'echo $HOME', then the script receives the argument 'echo $HOME', rather than any interpolated value.

section.title: Requirements for scripts run on remote systems
section.p: A script must include a shebang (#!) line specifying the interpreter. For example, for a script written in Bash, provide the path to the Bash interpreter: #!/bin/bash echo hello

section.title: Requirements for scripts run on remote systems
section.p: supports the extensions .ps1, .rb, and .pp. To enable other file extensions, add them to your configuration file, as follows: winrm: extensions: [.py, .pl]
